headline: Shredded Tofu Recipe
description: For lack of a snappier marketing term, these bean curd noodles—also referred to as tofu strands or shredded tofu on the packaging—have been taking the place of wheat noodles in my kitchen when I'm in the mood for a flour-free staple.
name: Shredded Tofu Recipe
keywords: Asian, bean curd, oyster sauce, Seriously Asian, soy sauce, tofu
recipeIngredient: 10 ounces vegetables for stir-frying, such as asparagus, broccoli, bok choy, washed and cut into 1-inch segments

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a pot of water to boil and parboil the tofu strands for 5 minutes. Drain and set aside.

Add the parboiled bean curd strands to the wok along with the ingredients for simmering. Simmer for 4 to 6 minutes, until the strands are softened but still al-dente and all but one teaspoon of the liquid has boiled away. Add the vegetables back to the wok and mix. Serve hot or at room temperature.
- serves 4 as an appetizer or side dish -
Bring a pot of water to boil and parboil the tofu strands for 5 minutes. Drain and set aside. Parboil the celery for 1 minute. Drain and set the celery in a bowl of ice water.

Place the parboiled bean curd strands in a saucepan along with the ingredients for simmering. Simmer for 4 to 6 minutes, until the strands are softened but still al dente and all but one teaspoon of the liquid has boiled away. Add the celery and toss to mix. Drizzle in the sesame oil and add salt to taste. Serve at room temperature or cold.

review.reviewBody:
@buffiw, don't know where you are located, but I found mine at a Super H Market in Atlanta GA. 

Stumbled on this old thread as I was searching for recipes using tofu shreds. I did a cold salad but the tofu shreds were SUPER tough. I boiled them for more than a few minutes, but I am wondering if the store froze them and that is why they were so chewy. Anybody know what the texture of frozen and thawed shreds is? These were definitely chewier than al dente pasta and didn't seem to be getting softer the longer they cooked.

I have been looking for shredded tofu everywhere. I can't even find it online. What is the brand that you use? I LOVE shredded tofu when I can get it in a restaurant. I would really like to cook with it at home. Thank you for your help.

@androgyn: I tried asking for dòufu miàn when I couldn't find shredded tofu at my Chinese market, however that ended up confusing the clerks who led me to shirataki after scratching their heads. A helpful stranger, however, taught me to read 豆乾絲 as dòu gān sī. The clerk didn't know what that was either, but he was able to read it on the package when we finally found what I was looking for.

@rarerollingobject: My family's always called them doufou mein, but they might have an actual other name. I think they're made from pressed tofu, which is somewhere between dried and fresh, I guess...

Cassaendra - it tastes like firm tofu or yuba. Also, after its brief parboiling in boiling water, I would really recommend that it gets seasoned. Unlike pasta, it doesn't taste too flavorful if it's sparsely dressed. 

To clarify, I've never found them packaged in liquid. The fresher they are, and if the store hasn't done frozen them, they should be relatively tender.
